title: Participation and Data Contribution
text:
To achieve broad geographic and ecological coverage, this project invites researchers to contribute plant tissue samples, extracted DNA, and/or whole-genome sequencing data. The project is designed to be flexible, allowing contributors to participate according to their available resources while adhering to shared standards that ensure data comparability and reproducibility.
Contributors may participate by:

sending plant tissues preserved in silica gel,
sending extracted genomic DNA, and/or
sharing whole-genome sequencing data generated independently.

title: Participation and Data Contribution
text:
Initial contact
Contact the coordinating team to express interest and indicate the type of contribution (plant tissue, DNA, and/or genomic data).

title: Participation and Data Contribution
text:
Sampling and preservation

Collect young, healthy leaf tissue when possible.
Preserve tissue immediately in silica gel until fully desiccated.
Clearly label each sample with a unique identifier.

title: Participation and Data Contribution
text:
Metadata recording
Record standardized metadata for each sample, including (at minimum): - Geographic coordinates and locality description - Habitat and environmental context - Sampling date and collector - Preservation method

title: Participation and Data Contribution
text:
DNA extraction or sequencing
Contributors may extract genomic DNA the provided guidelines, orPerform whole-genome sequencing locally using short- or long-read technologies.

title: Participation and Data Contribution
text:
Sample or data submission
Ship silica-dried tissues or extracted DNA provided instructions, or share raw sequencing reads and associated metadata through the designated data-transfer platform.

title: Participation and Data Contribution
text:
Data integration and acknowledgment
All contributions will be curated centrally, integrated into downstream analyses, and appropriately acknowledged through co-authorship or formal data citation, depending on the level of contribution.

title: International Water Hyacinth Genomics Initiative
text:
Objectives

Generate a global genomic database of Pontederia crassipes (Water Hyacinth) using whole-genome sequencing and complementary genomic approaches.
Characterize genetic diversity and population structure of P. crassipes across the native and invaded ranges.
Reconstruct invasion routes and dispersal pathways of P. crassipes at regional and global scales.
Identify genomic regions associated with adaptation of P. crassipes, invasiveness, and environmental tolerance.
Promote international collaboration and data sharing among P. crassipes researchers, institutions, and management agencies.

title: International Water Hyacinth Genomics Initiative
text:
Scope of the Initiative
The initiative is an open and collaborative framework designed to welcome contributions from researchers worldwide. Participation may include:

Providing plant tissue or DNA samples from well-documented populations.
Contributing raw whole-genome sequencing data or assembled genomes.
Sharing associated metadata, including geographic location, habitat type, sampling date, and ecological context.
Participating in joint analyses, publications, and related activities.

title: Methodological Framework
text:
Collaboration Model
This initiative is designed to be a distributed and inclusive consortium.

An open call for participation to research groups worldwide.
Clear guidelines on data ownership, authorship, and acknowledgment.
Opportunities for co-authored publications and thematic working groups.
Regular communication through virtual meetings, workshops, and shared online platforms.

Participation levels are flexible, enabling contributors to engage based on their resources and interests.
Beyond initial data generation, the initiative aims to:

Serve as a ‚Äúliving genomic resource‚Äù, continuously expanded with new samples and data.
Integrate genomic information with ecological, climatic, and distributional data.
Support training and capacity building, particularly in regions heavily affected by the invasion.
Provide a model framework applicable to other invasive species.

title: Methodological Framework
text:
Sampling Strategy
A coordinated sampling strategy will aim to cover:

The native range of the species.
Multiple invaded regions across continents.
Diverse environmental and ecological conditions (multiple habitats).

To ensure data comparability, contributors will be encouraged to follow standardized sampling and preservation protocols. They will also be provided with detailed guidelines for tissue collection, DNA extraction, and storage.

title: Methodological Framework
text:
Genomic Data Generation
The core genomic approach will be whole-genome sequencing (WGS) using either short- or long-read technologies. Depending on the available resources, the following sequencing strategies may be employed:

Resequencing of multiple individuals across populations.
Hybrid assemblies combining short and long reads.

title: Methodological Framework
text:
Data Management and Curation
All genomic data will be: - Stored in a centralized database with standardized formats.

Linked to comprehensive metadata records.
Submitted, when possible, to public repositories (e.g., international nucleotide sequence databases), following FAIR data principles (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable).

Quality control pipelines and documentation will be developed to ensure the reliability and reproducibility of the data.
